data.body:
> I'm also working on a generic exporter for 3D Max that will export the entire scene (cameras, lights, geometries, lines, animated objects using keyframes, animated objects using morph targets). Do you think it would be useful?

It sounds useful indeed. Are you exporting to the new format though?

Hello,

I have checked the latest JSOM format (4.3 if I'm not mistaken). Unfortunately this format does not provide enough information required for me to create a generic exporter for 3D Max.
What I'm trying to do is to make a very easy to use exporter where you only have 1 window in 3D max and this will automatically export the entire scene, and give the user access to all the exported parts using their original name from 3D Max.
So far I managed to create 3 categories of objects (geometry, lights, cameras). All of these objects can have animated key-frames,and the geometry can be also morphed. One of the most important thing that I need in order to be able to export all the geometry's animation properly is the pivot point and I noticed there isn't any option to export this.
I still have a lot work to do. I will post a link once I have a working version of it.

A decent exporter for max would be handy for me. I've currently been using openCollada to get my meshes into the engine and exporting dummy objects for camera / light animation. I've learnt a bit of code/ three.js enough to create and assign pbr materials and linking up matrices. I've been having problems with ThreeJSExporter.ms getting Morph Targets out. I think it's partly because I'm not sure how the script expects the scene setup in max.I've tried using the Morpher modifier as well as a skinned animation. Is there any documentation for how it's supposed to be used? I'm using the horse example TJS scene to debug the lack of morph target but the exporter has so far given me still/static meshes. Ideally what I'm trying to acheive is to bake down a very complex rig to point cache / vertex animation and this seems like the best way currently of doing it. Or is it?
Have you tried exporting as FBX and using the FBXLoader?

I've just done some more investigating and it looks like there are two FBXLoaders (FBXLoader.js & FBXLoader2.js) available. By looking inside those files it seems neither support morph targets, point cache, lights or cameras. @mesealexan I know this thread is a couple of years old but is your enhanced max exporter available anywhere? I've tried your .js exporter (ThreeJSExporter.ms) and I couldn't get morph targets to appear at all until I opened up the exported .js file and found all the MT keys are labelled FRAME000. By manually editing/incrementing these I got it to work. I'm guessing perhaps something's changed in newer versions of max.
